Issues.Title: Deep selector is broken in production mode
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17

### Reproduction link
Sorry for too busy and this is a build issue, if needed, I will provide a repo this weekend **but probably doesn't need**

### Steps to reproduce
Although this maybe a `less.js` bug, but seems only vue-loader(exactly `@vue/component-compiler-utils` and maybe angular use but I'm not familiar with it) relays on this to do it's own work, and since vue-loader repo seems not active, so I will report here to let more users could find this(There were already many issues about deep selector so I think this won't be offensive)

Vue-loader depends on `@vue/component-compiler-utils` which could [process deep selector](https://github.com/vuejs/component-compiler-utils/blob/master/lib/stylePlugins/scoped.ts#L35-L44), but this needs `less-loader`(exactly `less.js`) to process the css correctly. But in production mode, the result css after processed by `less` is **wrong**, because:

1. The `/deep/` syntax will be [considered a combinator](https://github.com/less/less.js/blob/master/lib/less/parser/parser.js#L1242-L1253)


2. And then when [process a combinator](https://github.com/less/less.js/blob/master/lib/less/tree/combinator.js#L19-L22), when the `compress` flag(**in production it's `true` by default but in development is `false`**) is `true`, the result will be `''   combinator   ''`(i.e. `/deep/`), but it should be `' '  + combinator +  ' '`(i.e. " /deep/ "). I.e. there needs a space before and after the combinator. But in production mode it's not, so all deep selectors won't work in production mode. 

IMO, maybe `less.js` is right because combinators usually are '>', '+', '~', '^'...  **These combinators still work even there is no space before and after them.** On the other hand, `/deep/` is a 'feature' used by Vue rather than **pure CSS**, so `less.js` doesn't consider this is passable.

### What is expected?
`div { /deep/ a { color: red; } }` -> `div a {color: red;}`

### What is actually happening?
`div { /deep/ a { color: red; } }` -> `div/deep/a {color: red;}`

### Versions
less: 3.8.1
vue-loader: 15.4.1

Issues.Title: Vue's instance _events object with ids
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Currently `_events` object contains event names as keys and arrays of listeners as values.

Let's say we have `Component A`, `Component B`, `Component C`. Both `Component A` and `Component B` listen to `'some-event'` event, which is emitted by `Component C`. Also `Component A` listens to `'another-event'` event.

It would be good to pass also unique IDs, so then user can call smth like `this.$eventBus.$offAll()` inside `beforeDestroy()` hook of `Component A` and it will unsubscribe `Component A` from all events it listens to BUT saves `Component B` subscriptions.

### What does the proposed API look like?
`this.$eventBus.$offAll()` so we can save `this.$eventBus.$off()` functionality as it is now

Issues.Title: On SSR, do not escape RAW nodes
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
When rendering a script tag on server the content is escaped, breaking the js code.

```html
<script>
  var x = "y";
</script>
```

is rendered as 

```html
<script>
  var x = "y";
</script>
```


### What does the proposed API look like?
A solution would be to allow users to define what to be escaped, to override this map

Issues.Title: Non-Deterministic CSS ordering for extracted CSS in an SSR App
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/brophdawg11/vue-ssr-css-ordering](https://github.com/brophdawg11/vue-ssr-css-ordering)

### Steps to reproduce
Reproduction steps are outlined in the README in the github repo.

### What is expected?
In both development and production builds, the extracted CSS stylesheets should be loaded in a deterministic order.  

I believe from reading various semi-related github issues that the order corresponds with the import order via webpack.  If that is the case for SSR as well, I would expect the order to be `app.css -> home.css -> about.css` since the `App.vue` file is loaded statically, and `Home.vue` and `About.vue` are loaded dynamically via routes in that order.

Either way, I would expect global styles from `App.vue` to always be loaded first, followed by dynamic-route styles, allowing for a proper cascade. 

### What is actually happening?
I think there are two issues at play:

**Primary Issue**: In development mode, the `app.css` file is incorrectly loaded _after_ the `about.css` file, breaking the cascade for contents of `About.vue`.

**Secondary Issue**: In production mode, the `app.css` file is properly loaded first, but then `about.css` is loaded prior to `home.css` even though they are imported in the reverse order and even when SSR-ing the home page.

---

### Additional Notes

I'm trying to determine what feels like the optimal solution, and I think there are a few options, in a loose descending order of "optimal", and likely increasing order of feasibility:

1. Global styles from the root `App.vue` component would always be loaded first, followed by the only the styles for the component matched for the current route.  Additional route-specific styles would be loaded on demand when routing.  I understand this is likely beyond the scope of the bundle renderer and potentially something to be implemented by the application itself.
2. Global styles from the root `App.vue` component would always be loaded first, followed by styles for the current route-component, followed by styles for additional route-components.
3. Global styles from the root `App.vue` component would always be loaded first, followed by styles for route-level components, in import-order (i.e., in route-declaration order)



It is also worth noting that my specific scenario in my larger app is slightly different, but I wasn't able to quite reproduce it exactly in this minimal repo, and I'm not quite sure why.  In my specific app case, I have an `App.vue` and 3 dynamic routes defined in the order:

* Home
* Page 1
* Page 2

In development mode, my stylesheets are included in the order:   page1, app, home, page2.

In production mode, my stylesheets are included in the order:   home, page1, page2, app

So in the demo repo, the production build is correct insofar as it doesn't break the cascade for either route, and the development build is incorrect for only one of the routes.  

In my actual app, the development mode only breaks the cascade for the page1 route, while the production build breaks it for all routes.

### What problem does this feature solve?

```

    component: Error
}
```

When a user visit `my-site.com/random-inexisting-url`, the url doesn't change and it displays the error page. (this is what we want)

*** 

Now, how to to do the same with dynamic routes?

Example: 
- there is a route like `my-site.com/pages/:id` 
- the user visits `my-site.com/pages/inexisting-id`.

It is possible to manually redirect to the `/error` page with `router.push({ name: 'error' })` or a navigation guard, but it will change the url to `/error`. 

**Is it possible to keep the original url, but still display the error page?** 



### What does the proposed API look like?
something like `router.aliasTo({name: 'error' })`

Issues.Title: Query parameter types change on reload
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/vv2rrjm2p7](https://codesandbox.io/s/vv2rrjm2p7)





### Steps to reproduce
It helps to open the inline browser in a new window so you can see the native URL bar.

Click "say hello" or "say goodbye" to go to the respective page with no query param. Number should be blank and the type undefined.

Click the button to switch pages but set the number to 10. The number is set and the type is number.

You can also confirm that the param is being set in the URL bar.

Now reload the page (or copy the URL and load it in a fresh tab). The number will be set and display correctly, but the type will be string. You can confirm this in the Vue devtools.

### What is expected?
On a fresh load or reload, the type of the "number" param should be the same as it was when it was set by Vue. The type should be number.

### What is actually happening?
On reload, the type changes to string.

---
Frankly I don't care which type vue router gives to me. I would prefer the parsing happens automatically, so I get a number, but if I know I'll get a string, I can always call parseInt myself. The important thing is that there is no difference in types between loading from another page vs loading for the first time from a URL. ### What problem does this feature solve?
#### Background:

Remove TypeScipt type definition in this repository, and move them to [DefinitelyTyped](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped), so type definition development wouldn't be the tasks for Vuex maintainers. I would expect type definition development would be more active with this since it'll be easier to review/merge.

Type definition are removed. Users will have to install `@types/vuex`, but it will be more accurate/strict/up-to-date definition.
